Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Breakthrough: A Cyber-Physical Framework for Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Guided Magnetic NanoParticles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates a new type of cyber-physical system (CPS), comprising magnetic nanoparticles in a fluidic environment such as human tissue whose motion is controlled by a computer via a magnetic field. The research aims to develop computational and experimental tools to perform the dynamic modeling, closed loop control and experimental validation of such a system of nanoparticles under guidance and observation using a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) environment. The envisioned CPS infrastructure is composed of a new computational platform to perform 3D simulation, visualization and post-processing analysis of the aggregation and disaggregation process of magnetic nanoparticles within a fluidic environment like the small arteries and arterioles or fluid-filled cavities of the human body. It also includes the development of robust control algorithms for the guidance of a swarm of magnetic nanoparticles in a MRI environment. Experimental validation is to be performed in clinical MRI scanners and in customized laboratory test-beds that generate controllable magnetic fields able to move magnetic nanoparticles in fluidic environments.

Potential applications of this basic research include nano-robotic drug delivery systems, composed of a system of magnetic nanoparticles guided by MRI scanners for targeted drug delivery in the human body. The project integrates education through participation of graduate and undergraduate students in the research, and involvement of the PI and graduate students in several outreach activities for students in high and middle schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this research effort includes the creation of a new CPS framework that enables the successful design, fabrication, control and deployment of a suspension of magnetic nanoparticles in fluidic environments. Such control systems can be used for in vivo magnetic drug targeting to increase local drug concentrations for therapy and diagnosis. We have successfully developed a CPS framework and have demonstrated methodology to robustly control the position of an agglomeration of nanoparticles and their on demand disaggregation. We have applied this methodology to the targeting of pancreatic cancer cells.

Broader Impacts: This project created tools and understanding to increase the efficacy of magnetic particle control for applications from drug delivery to magneto-rheology. In addition, we developed a large program toward broader education and outreach activities which will promote interests in materials science, technology, engineering and mathematics fields. We worked to initiate undergraduate students (including students from under-represented groups) in research in cyber-physical systems. We are still working to establish collaborative projects in cyber-physical systems and robotics with the science and technology high schools of Massachusetts. This project has provided research experience for two PhD students, two Master students, and two undergraduate students.

Products: Our research work resulted in 15 conference presentations, a PhD thesis, a MS thesis, 3 high-impact peer-reviewed publications, with two more publications under review and two more in preparation.
